title: Monster level
data:
**Monster level** is the experience level of a monster. It is used in the calculation of a monster's [hit points](/wiki/Hit_points "Hit points") and [experience point](/wiki/Experience "Experience") value, and in [determining whether or not a monster's attack hits you](/wiki/To-hit "To-hit"). If the monster is a [spellcaster](/wiki/Monster_spell "Monster spell"), then a higher level means a larger spell repertoire, usually containing more dangerous spells. Also, your [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") uses monster level to decide whether or not to attack another monster.

The number of hit points of most monsters is [(monster level)d8](/wiki/D_notation "D notation"); because of that, monster level is also known as **hit dice**, a term from [Dungeons and Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_and_Dragons "Dungeons and Dragons"). This is the meaning of "HD", which appears in the bottom status line when you are [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph#Self-polymorph "Polymorph") into a monster.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Calculation of monster level](#Calculation_of_monster_level)
- [2 Exceptions](#Exceptions)
- [3 Monster level and hit points](#Monster_level_and_hit_points)
- [4 References](#References)

## Calculation of monster level

Each monster has a *base level*, which can be found in the information box on the monster's page. However, not every monster will be generated at its base level; monster level is influenced by level depth and the hero's experience level.

Specifically, when a monster is generated, its level is determined as follows:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

- Start with the monster's base level;
- If the level depth value is smaller than the monster's base level, subtract one;
- If the level depth value is bigger than the monster's base level, add one-fifth of the difference between the two (rounded down);
- If your experience level is higher than the monster's base level, add one-fourth of the difference between the two (rounded down);
- If the result is higher than 1.5 times the monster's base level (rounded down), then it is lowered to that number;
- If the result is higher than 49, then it is lowered to that number.

The final result is the monster's starting level.

If you are in the [Endgame](/wiki/Endgame "Endgame"), then your effective level depth is the depth of the Sanctum plus one half of your experience level. If you have the [Amulet of Yendor](/wiki/Amulet_of_Yendor "Amulet of Yendor") but are not in the Endgame, then your effective level depth is the depth of the Sanctum.

There are a few ways for a monster to gain levels. For more information about this, see [Growing up](/wiki/Growing_up "Growing up").

## Exceptions

The [Wizard of Yendor](/wiki/Wizard_of_Yendor "Wizard of Yendor") is an exception to these rules. His level is 30, plus the number of times he has been killed, up to a maximum of 49.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[Player monsters](/wiki/Player_monsters "Player monsters") that are generated when you arrive on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") or the final level of the [Wizard quest](/wiki/Wizard_quest "Wizard quest") are another exception. They are generated at a random level, between 15 and 30 for the Astral Plane, and between 1 and 16 for the Wizard quest.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Similarly, your [guardian angel](/wiki/Angel "Angel") on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") is generated at a random level, between 15 and 22.[\[4\]](#cite_note-4)

Named demons and the mail daemon (which are internally defined with "monster level" greater than 49) are another exception. They have a fixed starting number of hit points, and their starting level is one-fourth of that number (rounded down):[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

| Monster                                        | Starting hit points | Starting level |
| ---------------------------------------------- | ------------------- | -------------- |
| [Mail daemon](/wiki/Mail_daemon "Mail daemon") | 100                 | 25             |
| [Juiblex](/wiki/Juiblex "Juiblex")             | 88                  | 22             |
| [Yeenoghu](/wiki/Yeenoghu "Yeenoghu")          | 100                 | 25             |
| [Orcus](/wiki/Orcus "Orcus")                   | 120                 | 30             |
| [Geryon](/wiki/Geryon "Geryon")                | 132                 | 33             |
| [Dispater](/wiki/Dispater "Dispater")          | 144                 | 36             |
| [Baalzebub](/wiki/Baalzebub "Baalzebub")       | 166                 | 41             |
| [Asmodeus](/wiki/Asmodeus "Asmodeus")          | 198                 | 49             |
| [Demogorgon](/wiki/Demogorgon "Demogorgon")    | 200                 | 50             |

Another exception is self-polymorph. When you polymorph into a monster, your hit dice (HD) will be equal to the monster's base level, without adjustment for dungeon depth or your natural form's level.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

## Monster level and hit points

- The number of hit points of most monsters is (monster level)d8.[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) Exceptions are [golems](/wiki/Golem "Golem"), the [Riders](/wiki/Rider "Rider"), the named demons, adult [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon"), [elementals](/wiki/Elemental "Elemental") created on their home planes, level 0 monsters, player monsters generated when you arrive on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") or [Wizard quest](/wiki/Wizard_quest "Wizard quest")[\[8\]](#cite_note-8), and your [guardian angel](/wiki/Angel "Angel") on the Astral Plane.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9) For more details, see [the hit points article](/wiki/Hit_points#Monster "Hit points").
- When you are polymorphed into a monster, your monster form's hit points are (HD)d8. Exceptions to this are [golems](/wiki/Golem "Golem"), adult [dragons](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon"), [elementals](/wiki/Elemental "Elemental") (if you polymorph into one on its home plane), and HD:0 monsters.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1755](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/makemon.c#L1755)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1762](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/makemon.c#L1762)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 142](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/mplayer.c#L142)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/minion.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 501](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/minion.c#L501)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 995](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/makemon.c#L995)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/polyself.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 701](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/polyself.c#L701)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 980](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/makemon.c#L980)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 143](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/mplayer.c#L143)
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [src/minion.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 502](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/minion.c#L502)
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [src/polyself.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 702-L714](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.6_Released/src/polyself.c#L702-L714)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.6. Click here for more information.](/images/5/57/Nh366-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.6. Click here for more information.")
html:
Monster level

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Monster level is the experience level of a monster. It is used in the calculation of a monster's hit points and experience point value, and in determining whether or not a monster's attack hits you. If the monster is a spellcaster, then a higher level means a larger spell repertoire, usually containing more dangerous spells. Also, your pet uses monster level to decide whether or not to attack another monster.

The number of hit points of most monsters is (monster level)d8; because of that, monster level is also known as hit dice, a term from Dungeons and Dragons. This is the meaning of "HD", which appears in the bottom status line when you are polymorphed into a monster.

Contents

  • 1 Calculation of monster level
  • 2 Exceptions
  • 3 Monster level and hit points
  • 4 References

Calculation of monster level

Each monster has a base level, which can be found in the information box on the monster's page. However, not every monster will be generated at its base level; monster level is influenced by level depth and the hero's experience level.

Specifically, when a monster is generated, its level is determined as follows:[1]

  • Start with the monster's base level;
  • If the level depth value is smaller than the monster's base level, subtract one;
  • If the level depth value is bigger than the monster's base level, add one-fifth of the difference between the two (rounded down);
  • If your experience level is higher than the monster's base level, add one-fourth of the difference between the two (rounded down);
  • If the result is higher than 1.5 times the monster's base level (rounded down), then it is lowered to that number;
  • If the result is higher than 49, then it is lowered to that number.

The final result is the monster's starting level.

If you are in the Endgame, then your effective level depth is the depth of the Sanctum plus one half of your experience level. If you have the Amulet of Yendor but are not in the Endgame, then your effective level depth is the depth of the Sanctum.

There are a few ways for a monster to gain levels. For more information about this, see Growing up.

Exceptions

The Wizard of Yendor is an exception to these rules. His level is 30, plus the number of times he has been killed, up to a maximum of 49.[2]

Player monsters that are generated when you arrive on the Astral Plane or the final level of the Wizard quest are another exception. They are generated at a random level, between 15 and 30 for the Astral Plane, and between 1 and 16 for the Wizard quest.[3]

Similarly, your guardian angel on the Astral Plane is generated at a random level, between 15 and 22.[4]

Named demons and the mail daemon (which are internally defined with "monster level" greater than 49) are another exception. They have a fixed starting number of hit points, and their starting level is one-fourth of that number (rounded down):[5]

Monster Starting hit points Starting level
Mail daemon 100 25
Juiblex 88 22
Yeenoghu 100 25
Orcus 120 30
Geryon 132 33
Dispater 144 36
Baalzebub 166 41
Asmodeus 198 49
Demogorgon 200 50

Another exception is self-polymorph. When you polymorph into a monster, your hit dice (HD) will be equal to the monster's base level, without adjustment for dungeon depth or your natural form's level.[6]

Monster level and hit points

  • The number of hit points of most monsters is (monster level)d8.[7] Exceptions are golems, the Riders, the named demons, adult dragons, elementals created on their home planes, level 0 monsters, player monsters generated when you arrive on the Astral Plane or Wizard quest[8], and your guardian angel on the Astral Plane.[9] For more details, see the hit points article.
  • When you are polymorphed into a monster, your monster form's hit points are (HD)d8. Exceptions to this are golems, adult dragons, elementals (if you polymorph into one on its home plane), and HD:0 monsters.[10]

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1755
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 1762
  3. ↑ src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 142
  4. ↑ src/minion.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 501
  5. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 995
  6. ↑ src/polyself.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 701
  7. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 980
  8. ↑ src/mplayer.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 143
  9. ↑ src/minion.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 502
  10. ↑ src/polyself.c in NetHack 3.6.6, line 702-L714

rawPage:
'''Monster level''' is the experience level of a monster. It is used in the calculation of a monster's [[hit points]] and [[Experience|experience point]] value, and in [[to-hit|determining whether or not a monster's attack hits you]].
If the monster is a [[Monster spell|spellcaster]], then a higher level means a larger spell repertoire, usually containing more dangerous spells. Also, your [[pet]] uses monster level to decide whether or not to attack another monster.

The number of hit points of most monsters is [[D notation|(monster level)d8]]; because of that, monster level is also known as '''hit dice''', a term from [[Dungeons and Dragons]]. This is the meaning of "HD", which appears in the bottom status line when you are [[Polymorph#Self-polymorph|polymorphed]] into a monster.

==Calculation of monster level==

Each monster has a ''base level'', which can be found in the information box on the monster's page. However, not every monster will be generated at its base level; monster level is influenced by level depth and the hero's experience level.

Specifically, when a monster is generated, its level is determined as follows:{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1755|nethack=3.6.6}}
*Start with the monster's base level;
*If the level depth value is smaller than the monster's base level, subtract one;
*If the level depth value is bigger than the monster's base level, add one-fifth of the difference between the two (rounded down);
*If your experience level is higher than the monster's base level, add one-fourth of the difference between the two (rounded down);
*If the result is higher than 1.5 times the monster's base level (rounded down), then it is lowered to that number;
*If the result is higher than 49, then it is lowered to that number.
The final result is the monster's starting level.

If you are in the [[Endgame]], then your effective level depth is the depth of the Sanctum plus one half of your experience level. If you have the [[Amulet of Yendor]] but are not in the Endgame, then your effective level depth is the depth of the Sanctum.

There are a few ways for a monster to gain levels. For more information about this, see [[Growing up]].

==Exceptions==

The [[Wizard of Yendor]] is an exception to these rules. His level is 30, plus the number of times he has been killed, up to a maximum of 49.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1762|nethack=3.6.6}}

[[Player monsters]] that are generated when you arrive on the [[Astral Plane]] or the final level of the [[Wizard quest]] are another exception. They are generated at a random level, between {{rn1|16|15| and }} for the Astral Plane, and between 1 and 16 for the Wizard quest.{{refsrc|src/mplayer.c|142|nethack=3.6.6}}

Similarly, your [[Angel|guardian angel]] on the [[Astral Plane]] is generated at a random level, between {{rn1|8|15| and }}.{{refsrc|src/minion.c|501|nethack=3.6.6}}

Named demons and the mail daemon (which are internally defined with "monster level" greater than 49) are another exception. They have a fixed starting number of hit points, and their starting level is one-fourth of that number (rounded down):{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|995|nethack=3.6.6}}

{|class=prettytable
|-
! Monster !! Starting hit points !! Starting level
|-
| [[Mail daemon]] || 100 || 25
|-
| [[Juiblex]] || 88 || 22 
|-
| [[Yeenoghu]] || 100 || 25 
|-
| [[Orcus]] || 120 || 30
|-
| [[Geryon]] || 132 || 33
|-
| [[Dispater]] || 144 || 36
|-
| [[Baalzebub]] || 166 || 41
|-
| [[Asmodeus]] || 198 || 49
|-
| [[Demogorgon]] || 200 || 50
|}

Another exception is self-polymorph. When you polymorph into a monster, your hit dice (HD) will be equal to the monster's base level, without adjustment for dungeon depth or your natural form's level.{{refsrc|src/polyself.c|701|nethack=3.6.6}}

==Monster level and hit points==

*The number of hit points of most monsters is (monster level)d8.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|980|nethack=3.6.6}} Exceptions are [[golem]]s, the [[Rider]]s, the named demons, adult [[dragon]]s, [[elemental]]s created on their home planes, level 0 monsters, player monsters generated when you arrive on the [[Astral Plane]] or [[Wizard quest]]{{refsrc|src/mplayer.c|143|nethack=3.6.6}}, and your [[Angel|guardian angel]] on the Astral Plane.{{refsrc|src/minion.c|502|nethack=3.6.6}} For more details, see [[Hit points#Monster|the hit points article]].
*When you are polymorphed into a monster, your monster form's hit points are (HD)d8. Exceptions to this are [[golem]]s, adult [[dragon]]s, [[elemental]]s (if you polymorph into one on its home plane), and HD:0 monsters.{{refsrc|src/polyself.c|702-L714|nethack=3.6.6}}
